But I was relieved when I heard Richard Pryor had died. Everyone's saying "goodbye to the laughs" and other shit like that, but my God, have any of you seen the shape he was in over the past decade or so? Multiple Sclerosis ravaged the poor man's body, and he was a shadow of his former self even in 1997's "Lost Highway" (where he had a small cameo).

I fucking hate when people make the death of someone famous whose relevancy* has passed such a huge tragedy in their own life. Wherever Richard Pryor is, I'm sure he's grateful to have his suffering end. 

Phil Hartman, Chris Farley, Bill Hicks and Sam Kinison dying in their primes were tragedies. Richard Pryor's death was completely different. His death won't leave us with any absences and "what ifs."

Rent his concerts on DVD, laugh and learn from a comic legend. Don't act like our culture now has a void that will never be replaced. The real Richard Pryor died years ago--that was the real tragedy.

 

*that is not to say that Pryor's standup is not relevant, but due to his illness he wasn't creating anything new. I suppose I really just mean saying goodbye to the laughs is fucking pointless, because they still exist. Go rent "Blazing Saddles"

My grandfather's death didn't really hit me until this morning when I was talking to my grandmother and she told me Poppa will be cremated with a package of Beechnut chewing tobacco.

 

My entire life I remember seeing packages in Poppa's garage and having no idea what they were, but being curious about them. I could always smell it too, and although I had no idea that the smell correlated with the packages until much later, there was always something comforting in that smell--and Poppa's big goofy grin.

It's kind of surreal when you find out your grandfather who has survived a stroke, a brain tumor, diabetes, heart surgery, skin cancer and even a toe removal due to poor circulation has died from falling down the stairs.

He broke his neck and fractured his skull. My Dad hit a deer on the way to get there. When he got there my grandfather was in a body bag and there was a pool of blood on the stairs.

Hunter S. Thompson's remains shot from cannon

Associated Press

WOODY CREEK, Colo. -- Bill Murray, George McGovern and dozens of Hunter S. Thompson's friends gathered Saturday to give the iconoclastic journalist an unsolemn farewell, with blow-up dolls, liquor and a tower built to blast his ashes into the sky.

"He loved explosions," explained his wife, Anita Thompson.

She said the tower, shrouded by tarps for days, was modeled after Thompson's Gonzo logo: a clenched fist, made symmetrical with two thumbs, rising from the hilt of a dagger.

The counterculture author's ashes, intermingled with fireworks, were to be fired from it Saturday evening in a field between Thompson's home and a tree-covered canyon wall.

Security guards kept reporters and the public away from the writer's Owl Farm compound Saturday as the 250 invited guests arrived, but Thompson's fans scouted the surrounding hills for the best view of the celebration of the author's life.

"Nothing could ever top this weekend unless someone offered me a job paying $50 an hour for the rest of my life," said Trevor Long, a college freshman from Keller, Texas, who became a fan after finding his father's collections of Thompson's writing.

Thompson killed himself six months ago at his home near Aspen, but the memorial was planned as a party, with plenty of alcohol, reminiscences, readings from Thompson's works and performances by both Lyle Lovett and the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band.

The author's longtime illustrator, Ralph Steadman, and actors Sean Penn and Johnny Depp, close friends of Thompson, were among the stars on the invitation list. Depp portrayed Thompson in the 1998 movie version of "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas: A Savage Journey to the Heart of the American Dream," perhaps the writer's best-known work.

"Over the last few months I've learned that he really touched people more deeply than I had realized," said Thompson's son, Juan.

Thompson's longtime friend George Stranahan lamented the Hollywood-style production.

"I am pretty sure it isn't how Hunter would have done it," Stranahan said. "But when your friends make a mistake you support them."

Anita Thompson said Depp funded much of the celebration.

"We had talked a couple of times about his last wishes to be shot out of a cannon of his own design," Depp told The Associated Press last month. "All I'm doing is trying to make sure his last wish comes true. I just want to send my pal out the way he wants to go out."

Thompson was credited along with Tom Wolfe and Gay Talese with helping pioneer New Journalism -- he dubbed his version "gonzo journalism" -- in which the writer was an essential component of the story.

He often portrayed himself as wildly intoxicated as he reported on figures such as Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton. At the height of the Watergate era, he said Richard Nixon represented "that dark, venal, and incurably violent side of the American character."

Besides the 1972 classic about Thompson's visit to Las Vegas, he also wrote an expose on the Hell's Angels and "Fear and Loathing: On the Campaign Trail '72," in which the central character was a snarling, drug- and alcohol-crazed observer and participant.

The Kentucky-born writer also was the model for Garry Trudeau's balding "Uncle Duke" in the comic strip "Doonesbury."

In this now-chic resort community, he proudly fired his guns whenever he wanted, let peacocks have the run of the land and ran for sheriff in 1970 under the Freak Power Party banner.

Thompson shot himself in his kitchen Feb. 20, apparently unable to handle his declining health. One close acquaintance suggested Thompson did not want old age to dictate the circumstances of his death. Anita Thompson said no suicide note was left.

Composer David Amram, a friend of Thompson since the early 1960s, said Thompson had never expected to be successful taking on President Nixon during the Watergate era. "He thought he would be banned or put on an enemies' list," he said.

Thompson made himself the centerpiece of his stories "to show that a regular person could be in the midst of the craziness of the time," Amram said. "He was our historian."

Well, Broken Flowers was a delightful little film. Though, I can't help but think of it as "Lost in Translation" part deux....the return trip home.

After the movie Jen and I had to stop to get gas. As she parked and went to get out of the car, we noticed we were unintentionally being mooned by a girl getting gas in the car next to us. She was wearing one of those tennis skirt type dealies, either with a thong or no underwear, because we totally saw lots of ass. We weren't sure if she was drunk or an idiot (probably not mutually exclusive) but the fact she and her friend had a Tennessee license plate tilted it toward the latter. Someone, somewhere, got some that night. 

Then some dude pulls up who looks JUST like Steve Verstrate. He's blaring "Pour Some Sugar on Me." Except he was a total tool...one of those guys who wears his shirt collars up instead of the way you're supposed to. 

I thought I was in a David Lynch movie written by Richard Linklater or something.


Anyway, the only reason we saw Broken Flowers last night was because the Des_Ark show I was supposed to go to got canceled because of plumbing issues at The Che Cafe. Luckily I got in touch with the band and they're listing me tonight for their show in Anaheim, due to its being sold out. I can't wait because their "Loose Lips Sink Ships" really is my favorite album of this year so far...

On Friday night Jen and I saw Our Lady Peace at Brick By Brick, a venue I'll most likely never go to again. It was, honestly, too Buffalo Bar-ish for my liking. And the fans were strange. They were those people who have like 5 favorite bands: Our Lady Peace, Creed, Pearl Jam, maybe Stone Temple Pilots and Maybe Soundgarden. Anyway, the tickets were like 7 bucks and it was for charity.

Well, immediately upon hitting the stage I could tell the band was Canadian. They all looked like Barenaked Ladies/Moxy Fruvous types, except for the singer. He was actually pretty fucking intense live, and I couldn't help but think what a drug problem and more creative musicians behind him would have done for his career. They played mostly new songs, which seemed to be emulating some sort of Pearl Jam meets U2 aesthetic, which wasn't annoying but didn't bowl me over either. It was pretty much what I expected there...

But let me tell you: They ended the show with a killer rendition of "Starseed," the first song I ever heard from them back in 1997. But, it was also indicative of how big of a let down their career has been: The guitarist was wailing on his guitar, and you could tell his emotions were getting the better of him and he was about to start improv-ing, but he stopped and just started punching his guitar instead. 

To me, it was the epitome of major label/expectational/"sellout" restraint. 

They also played "Clumsy," "Naveed" and "Superman's Dead" which were, indeed, worth the price of admission.

Well. I shouldn't say that. I can make hide nor hair of it because I was there...but to make this work as an article will probably take everything I've got...

I just went through about 30ish promos, so Ilana, Nick, Dan, Steve, John and the new Nick can expect packages pretty soon. Dan's going to get the most, I think, though John is close. I'm going to wager that it'll be a toss-up between Nick and Dan as to who got the best bands, with Ilana coming a close third and Steve a close fourth (he's getting mostly instrumental stuff). new Nick has three comps coming his way though, so I'm sure he's going to get a decent amount of decent music...

the flaming lips doc came from netflix today. this excites me more than the free suicide girls doc i got from Epitaph that doesn't come out until August 30th. It's kinda crappy. i had no idea the founder of suicide girls was this kinda dorky girl who is veeery non-eloquent. 

"Um, yeah, so I decided to take pictures and had no idea it was going to branch out this far. it's a worldwide phenomenon"

Oh, really? Hot naked punk chicks? There's a market for that? Whoa!

Anyway, the DVD's just softcore porn. I thought it'd be a little more interesting than watching a girl perform live (or sometimes staged) then watching her strip for a photo shoot, then moving on to the next girl.

But I don't really know what else to expect. it's pretty much just a PR doc, not a documentary discussing the relevancy of a modern day burlesque in today's society. The closest they come to poignancy is when they say, "It's like a modern day burlesque show" and "Burlesque is becoming more popular these days"

Oh. Thanks.

I'm crabby because it's hot, mostly. But, yeah, after about the third girl I turned it off. perhaps it got better, though i'm not holding my breath.

The theme of the documentary seemed to be "I never thought I'd be able to/I never even thought about posing naked before because I don't have a perfect body"

Sorry, but have you seen the Suicide Girls? Not a plumper in sight...yikes. 




I'm not even sure what I'm saying anymore...

does the guy on the right look like anyone we know?

Saw War of The Worlds today, and have to agree with Mike that it was 1,000,000 times better than Signs. I'm not going to compare it to Independence Day because they're two completely different entities.

 

But, I enjoyed the psychological nature of this film, really, really loved the camera work. The only thing I didn't like was the broken-home reconciliation that every movie seems to have nowadays. Time magazine ripped Tim Robbins for overacting, but I thought he was pretty funny/weird and I could believe someone freaking out like that... 

Hmm...going to see Weird War. They're fantastic...

 

Did anyone see last week's Family Guy with the JFK Jr. gag? Stewie: "Even I found that to be in bad taste"

I pre-ordered the re-release of the first Arcade Fire EP today.

I have downloaded it, and it's not even that great, but I wanted it anyway.

who has heard the new foo fighters?

is not disc two the most beautiful mainstream record released in years?

i have a job interview tomorrow. wish me luck...

also, i just read that jarvis cocker is going to be in the new harry potter movie. i may have already known this, but perhaps not....

Jen and I pulled a double header of sorts yesterday, taking in a Dodgers/Padres game in San Diego followed by Enon, Thunderbirds are Now! and Sparrows.

We arrived just as Sparrows hit the stage...their sound (not them playing but what came out of the amps) was ridiculously loud for what kind of music they were playing (imagine Ben Folds with violins but without the personality and hilarious wordplay). They were so Canadian they didn't even say "aboot." They said, "aboat."

Thunderbirds are Now! were another Frenchkiss Records band I didn't like when I heard their album (Smoke and Smoke being the other), but after seeing them live, I'm in love...Imagine Q and Not U, but rock n roll. Sort of. 

Then Enon played. I think Toko was sick...she sang the first few songs (the ones that are delicate and electronic-ish and seem like they could have been on the lost in translation soundtrack) but not much else until the encore.

But when John took over the band got significantly heavier and it was, to say the least, awesome.



oh...and i'm fucking sick. not sure what it is, but my whole body is achey and ihave a little bit of a cough.

mother.

Just found out Des_Ark will be playing the Che Cafe in August or something.

this excites me.

i applied for three new jobs:

a copy editor at a shithole daily paper
an editorial assistant at a self-help book publishing company
a reporter at The North County Times...a 95,000 circ. paper.

I suppose you can guess which one would probably be the best monetarily, and even probably work-wise

but

the other two will have significantly better hours for me to continue to go to shows and take pics for aural minority.

but

i have to make a living at some point

 

ah well. wish me some sort of luck, I suppose.

Oh, and this list is for Carolyn. 10 CDs she must purchase (Not including Arcade Fire's Funeral, TV on the Radio's Desperate Youths Bloodthirsty Babes and Autolux's Future Perfect)

1) John Wilkes Booze: Five Pillars of Soul

2) Subtitle: Young Dangerous Heart

3) Busdriver: Fear of a Black Tangent

4) Xiu Xiu: La Foret    (anything by them really)

5) Kill Me Tomorrow: The Garbageman and the Prostitute

6) The Kills: No Wow

7) Murder By Death: Who Will Survive and What Will Be Left of Them

8) The Mars Volta: Frances The Mute

9) Les Savy Fav: Inches, Go Forth and The Cat and The Cobra (I know this is three, but, well...)

10) Madvillian: Madvillainy. (runner-up: MF DOOM: Mm...Food)

 

That list is in no particular order. Nor is it comprehensive.

 

Entourage was actually pretty boring tonight. I also saw and enjoyed Batman Begins. I have a lot of writing to do tomorrow, or at least transcribing. I have fallen in love with the band Weather. I just realized I left These Arms Are Snakes off that list. Dear God.

Josh and Zack are coming out to visit and we're going to a Yankees game up in Anaheim. and then going up to L.A. to see Year Future, I think. Saw Blood Brothers the other night. Didn't like them live at all. Big Business and Plot were way cooler. The Blood Brothers were just this big loud nondescript mess. Plot forgot to give me a plus one, so I had to call them. Funnily enough, they forgot to give Sonny Kay one too, and he runs Gold Standard Labs, so I didn't feel as bad.

sleep now. hopefully I'll get a new job.

It's been about a year and a half since I last updated, or so it seems.


I've been busy as hell of late. I seem to be getting an average of at least 2 promos a day. Usually it's five in one day, none the next, three the next, one the next, none the next, then four more.

But I can't say I'd rather be doing anything else. 

Went up to L.A. last night to see the fabulous new incarnation of Rose For Bohdan. Got some amazing shots. Will post a link to them and others when they go up on the site. (Out Hud were more than photogenic) 

Saw Trekkies two. It was not even remotely as amazing as the first one, but that's ok. The "filk" and Klingon Metal band were totally worth it. 

Ran into Sonny from Year Future, Justin, Bobby and Gabe from the Locust and Zack and K8 from Kill Me Tomorrow the other day at a show. Then saw Zack and Bobby a few days later at The Peppermints. I see Bobby at every show I go to. It makes me laugh. 

I'm rather scatter brained right now lots of f-ed up shit is going on back home (essentially my dad's developed paranoid schizophrenia. i wish i was exaggerating) it's pretty perilous back there now, and I'm stuck out here. but Zack is coming out to visit, so that's nice/fun/etc. I'm going to take him up to L.A. to see Business Lady and Year Future and also hopefully a baseball game. the neighbor kid is gonna take him surfing...

i just feel rather helpless, selfish, angry, depressed one moment, then happy the next (like when I found out the site got 8,000 some-odd hits yesterday, 3,000 more than our previous high). i'm too old to have to deal with this shit sometimes.


I dunno. 


things fall into place. 

things fall apart.
damn dude. the season finale of lost was a total mindfuck...
